title: Maritime Monitoring (AIS)
content:
# Maritime Monitoring with AIS

AIS (Automatic Identification System) is the maritime equivalent of ADS-B. Every large vessel broadcasts its identity, position, course, and speed.

## Frequencies

- **Channel 87B:** 161.975 MHz
- **Channel 88B:** 162.025 MHz

Both channels are used simultaneously with TDMA (time-division multiple access).

## What Ships Broadcast

### Every 2-10 seconds (dynamic data):
- Position (lat/lon)
- Speed over ground
- Course over ground
- Rate of turn
- Navigation status

### Every 6 minutes (static data):
- MMSI (9-digit unique ID)
- Vessel name and callsign
- Ship type and dimensions
- Destination and ETA

## AIS Classes

| Class | Who | Update Rate |
|-------|-----|------------|
| Class A | Large vessels (>300 GT) | 2-10 seconds |
| Class B | Pleasure craft | 30s - 3 min |
| AtoN | Buoys, lighthouses | 3 minutes |

## Reception Tips

Coastal locations are ideal. Even 20-30 miles inland with a good antenna on a mast, you'll receive plenty of maritime traffic. VHF signals travel well over water.

steps.title: Tune to AIS
steps.content: Set your SDR to 162.000 MHz centre frequency with 50 kHz bandwidth. The AIS decoder monitors both channels simultaneously.

steps.title: Watch the Maritime Map
steps.content: Vessels appear on the map with their real names, types, and routes. Click a vessel to see full details including destination and cargo type.

steps.title: Understanding MMSI
steps.content: Every vessel has a unique 9-digit MMSI. The first digits indicate the country: 2xx = UK, 3xx = US. You can look up vessel details using the MMSI on MarineTraffic.

quiz.question: What are the two AIS frequencies?
How often does a Class A vessel update its position?
quiz.explanation: Class A transponders update every 2-10 seconds depending on speed and turn rate.
